body:
> Thank you, @bmhm !

Thank YOU for merging! :) I am so happy that my first PR to the ASF was accepted this easily. :)
Please keep them going, @bmhm ! :-)
@coheigea could you please tell when you could check and review the PR? Thanks in advance.
:+1: , sounds great, thank you @steingebein! My appologies, did you push your changes? Thanks!

hi @reta, 
I changed the code and added a test case, please review it.

hey @steingebein, thanks a lot for the great work, I did two post-merge changes:
 - put back `running = false;`, so the polling threads would stop progressing, I believe this make sense
 - refactored your test case to use test doubles as other tests from `JMSDestinationTest` suite (no mocks)
Please let me know if you have any concerns or I missed something, thank you!

Hi @reta, thank you for review & finish this pull request.

`running = false;` makes the poller threads stopping/failing faster, so I think that's better.

Your test changes: my test case was intended to test multiple poller-threads failing, so they call `handleException` parallel. In your test case the error handling runs not parallel, because there's only one poller thread. If you remove `sychronized` and my changes in `ExceptionListener`, your test will not fail.
I created another branch with following changes to the test case:
- `concurrentConsumer` is set 10
- `FaultyConnection` will fail 5 times (more poller-threads will fail)
- verify that there was only one call to restartConnection() 

See  [CXF-8161 test case with parallel error handling](https://github.com/steingebein/cxf/commit/0dbf6c046b2b321d03474003104beae732c5ebf4)

If you like these changes I can create another pull request.
@steingebein thanks a lot, the test case looks good, yeah, could you please create a PR for it? Thanks!
@reta pull request created: https://github.com/apache/cxf/pull/614
Thanks @steingebein !
@dtsybulka It's on my TODO list, but realistically it will be early in the new year before I can review it properly.

@coheigea - Can you please let me know when this will be released? We just implemented a media type whitelisting feature, and the bug this fixes is stopping us from deploying.

Thanks!
Realistically with the holiday season - the second week of January I'd say.
That's great - thanks!
I replayed my changes to split CXF-8177 and CXF-8178 into 2 separate commits and I did some cleanups as well. Should be fine now.
The build failed on `org.apache.cxf.transport.jms.util.MessageListenerTest.testLocalTransaction`. But the same test is green on my computer.

> 
> 
> The build failed on `org.apache.cxf.transport.jms.util.MessageListenerTest.testLocalTransaction`. But the same test is green on my computer.

This test is a flaky one at the moment, unfortunately, nothing to worry about with respect to this PR.
Thanks !
@andymc12 please correct me if I am wrong, if we consider CDI-based deployments, the instances of the `MicroProfileClientProxyImpl` (and others) should be created as CDI beans, right?

> if we consider CDI-based deployments, the instances of the MicroProfileClientProxyImpl (and others) should be created as CDI beans, right?

@reta yes, it is done indirectly by creating the client proxy instance using the `CxfTypeSafeClientBuilder` from the `RestClientBean` / `RestClientExtension`.

Excellent, thanks @andymc12 , so here is my follow up question / concern: why won't we make `CxfTypeSafeClientBuilder` CDI-aware (using extension or alike) so the proxies are going to be managed by `BeanManager` and as such, could use `@Inject` annotation directly? In this case, the integration should work in all scenarios (managed, standalone, ...). Does it make sense?
I see two Jenkins failures in different JMS buckets - I don't think these are related to this change though, as I don't think JAX-RS is even involved in these buckets.
@andymc12 the JMS test failures should not be related, one of them is flaky for sure, second one became flaky recently, I know why, will address it, thanks.
It's just the flaky test failing, so I think this is ready for merge...
@andymc12 Should this be merged to 3.3.x-fixes as well?
@coheigea yes, I'll back port that now.  Thanks!
@reta am I missing something? my tests look good so far

hey @andymc12, sorry for the delay, finally found the time to finish the review:
 - `CDIUtils` and `CDIFacade`: we already use reflection-base `BeanManager` detection in `CDIInterceptorWrapper::createWrapper`, it think we should stick to one way to do it
 - may be `MicroProfileClientFactoryBean` is a better place for dealing with CDI & `ClientHeadersFactory`, which could be passed to `MicroProfileClientProxyImpl` in a similar way as `CDIInterceptorWrapper`. The `BeanManager` detection logic (whichever we pick), could be reused for both of them.

What do you think?

@reta
> CDIUtils and CDIFacade: we already use reflection-base BeanManager detection in CDIInterceptorWrapper::createWrapper, it think we should stick to one way to do it

Agreed.  I updated the CDIInterceptorWrapper to use CDIFacade/CDIUtils.

> may be MicroProfileClientFactoryBean is a better place for dealing with CDI & ClientHeadersFactory, which could be passed to MicroProfileClientProxyImpl in a similar way as CDIInterceptorWrapper. The BeanManager detection logic (whichever we pick), could be reused for both of them.

My latest changes reuse the BeanManager detection logic.  I'm not sure if moving the ClientHeadersFactory logic into MicroProfileClientFactoryBean will work since that is when the client proxy is being created.  It's possible the the rest client instance is created in one JAX-RS context (or outside of a JAX-RS request entirely) and then used in a different JAX-RS context.  So then the injection would need to occur on each request, right?

Thanks again!

Thanks @andymc12 , regarding

> My latest changes reuse the BeanManager detection logic. I'm not sure if moving the ClientHeadersFactory logic into MicroProfileClientFactoryBean will work since that is when the client proxy is being created. It's possible the the rest client instance is created in one JAX-RS context (or outside of a JAX-RS request entirely) and then used in a different JAX-RS context. So then the injection would need to occur on each request, right?

you are right, it might happen, but probably the same would apply to `CDIInterceptorWrapper`: it will pick up the interceptors from the different context. I don't know what is the best option to be fair, just an opinion if we have a single place to make the decisions (the factory bean), it would be much easier to reason about the outcome (proxy) and maintain it. The uncertainty with contexts may cause issues but I would leave the decision to you, I think you have a better view of the picture.

Thanks for the release, @coheigea - everything's working great!

For some weird reason, Github didn't send a notification, even with me watching releases for this repo.

Thanks for the approval - it looks like these changes may be causing some systest failures - some of them seem unrelated, but others are in the SSE bucket - I'll investigate a little more - it's possible I may need to tweak the tests.
@deki local build passed using java version "1.8.0_241"
thanks for adapting the test @amarkevich
Thanks @coheigea , just fixed it!
its Hudson specific failure - I'm unable to reproduce locally and try to sync failed tests with passing org.apache.cxf.osgi.itests
retest this please

@reta Thanks for the feedback. The conversation continues on the spec list - there's a note about UriBuilder referencing rfc-3986 - https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986. I've pushed a further commit to try and make this more generic by checking the path and raw scheme specific element.
@jgallimore thanks, I think we can get it in like that, a few comments please to address, thank you
@reta Thank you again for the feedback. I've hopefully addressed those items!
@jgallimore thank you!
@jgallimore thank you!

@amarkevich could you please sync up with @ffang on that, we wanted to switch to saaj-impl 1.5.1 as part of https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CXF-7910 (specifically, https://fisheye.apache.org/changelog/cxf?cs=49d34cf3a1583932779d39766b055bf49359da53) but he expressed the concerns  with this specific version, so we decided to stick to 1.3.x (for impl), thanks
ok

@coheigea  From commit log https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/jaxb-ri/commits/master, it moves to 2.4 stream after 2.3.3-b02.  To double check this, I already sent email to jaxb-dev list to ask if there is any plan to do a 2.3.3 release in the future. I'll post here after I get an update.
@natechadwick thank you, LGTM

Hi @coheigea,
I hope you are fine. Could you please let me know if you had a chance to check the PR.
Best Regards,
Dmitry

Tim, thanks for your contribution and the detailled description. Much appreciated. To me it looks good, I wonder if the Jenkins build with tests passes. Somehow the GitHub integration seems not have been triggered it.

Would you mind opening an issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/CXF/ here so that we have it documented in our release notes? Otherwise I can also do it.

Thanks for looking into this. I've created an issue:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CXF-8210
Feel free to update adjust if necessary.
Thanks for the PR, @timpeeters!

@jgallimore I am happy to merge this if you can't see a way around the sun dependency. Could you also raise a PR with ActiveMQ to port the change you made to pick up the look up name from the connectorPath variable in ManagementContext.
I can't see a way around the sun dependency at the moment. I've done the PR for ActiveMQ: https://github.com/apache/activemq/pull/465

Sorry that was a mistake, I'll revert that.

On Thu, 20 Feb 2020, 07:56 Colm O hEigeartaigh, <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@coheigea* commented on this pull request.
>
> Why delete the existing tests for getRegistryPort?
>
> 
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/cxf/pull/641?email_source=notifications&email_token=AAEF6EBCZVHBB6NMTPV6FSDRDYZSHA5CNFSM4KWQORD2YY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFWFIHK3DMKJSXC5LFON2FEZLWNFSXPKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOCWHPWII#pullrequestreview-361691937>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAEF6EABOV4K76ZQKGKL2S3RDYZSHANCNFSM4KWQORDQ>
> .
>
@reta any objections?

My main concern is using the javax.xml.ws.Holder object.   That would introduce a direct dependency from the JAX-RS frontend onto the JAX-WS API.   With Java8, that's not a huge deal as its in the JDK, but with Java11+, it is a problem.   My simple suggestion would be to create a private inner "holder" class of some sort just for that.
@dkulp is initial impl using AtomicReference fit the requirements?
Yep.  Replacing Holder with AtomicReference would work perfectly for this.

@dkulp That is right, I suggested to remove AtomicReference since this is sychronization primitive, this code snippet does not need sychronization. The small holder object would be simpler and lightweight I think.
Sorry, it'll be a few weeks before I can look at it, but it is on my radar for CXF 3.4.0.
ps sorry about this one.. we should have always checked null

Please backport to 3.3.X. 
And 3.1.X (I realize this is a stretch)
NP @adriancole ! Good it was caught :+1:
Thanks @andymc12 !
@andymc12 @coheigea guys if don't mind to take a look, it simplifies callback logic a lot
How would adding support to JAX-RS look like? Could we reuse parts of the code?

> How would adding support to JAX-RS look like? Could we reuse parts of the code?

In theoretically yes you can. But I have a lack of knowledge about JAX-RS. Due to this I don't want to add any code related to that.

@junhuhdev The idea is to shape this PR so the foundation is ready for JAX-RS (very likely without introducing JAX-RS support directly as per discussion with @shark300 on the ticket). I should be back on it in a few days to finish up the review.

Ok thanks looks promising. Looking forward to testing this implementation. 

Btw is support JAX-RS on the roadmap?
@junhuhdev certainly, https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CXF-8252
@deki Why not moving Apache BVal instead (latest version: 2.0.3)?
@ilgrosso CXF is not using BVal, is it?
@deki exactly: I was thinking why we don't switch to BVal rather than upgrading Hibernate Validator, as in its latest version BVal is implementing Bean Validation 2.x anyway.
Ok got it. Well I like the idea but it's not just drop-in replacement, for example I see references to org.hibernate.validator classes in samples

It should be only in [a class](https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/master/osgi/itests/src/test/java/org/apache/cxf/osgi/itests/jaxrs/BookStore.java) even though AFAICT there should never be need to explicitly call a given impl. 

Anyway, I understand such a change might not be completely on-scope here.
I'd suggest we try to finish this one and try the BVal changes afterwards.
@deki @amarkevich I think we could merge it like that guys, and keep Swagger Core 1.6.x on the radar, thoughts?
I raised an issue in Woodstox about the MSV shading: https://github.com/FasterXML/woodstox/issues/103
CC @steingebein

Hi @reta,

I think it's ok to remove the synchronized keyword from `restartConnection`, because `onException` in `ExceptionListener` is also synchronized. 
The fix from https://github.com/apache/cxf/pull/603 should not be affected.

Greetings

Hi @andymc12 , instead of using org.reactivestreams, why not using java >= 9 Flow? It will avoid a dependency already replaced and you don't want in most cases (when you dont use SSE or are on tjava LTS, ie java 11 today).

@andymc12 It seems like Reactive Streams is a good choice for now (and with JDK11 baseline, `Flow` API could be the replacement) but I would suggest to run Reactive Streams TCK tests against `SsePublisher` (https://github.com/reactive-streams/reactive-streams-jvm/tree/v1.0.3/tck), there are a number of requirements the implementation should follow (if would be more than happy to help with that).

@reta i didnt see the need of reactivestreams in MP (and it should stay like that to stay aligned on java). Issue starting to use it is to mix reactive styles accross impl and have to manage this dep, this is why i'd prefer to not use it where not needed (and SSE does not need it ;)).

@rmannibucau I found Reactive Streams to be good abstraction, every single reactive stream implementation supports it (so interop would be the least concern here I believe), afaik even MP does have own spec based of Reactive Streams (https://github.com/eclipse/microprofile-reactive-streams-operators). Certainly SSE impl does not need Reactive Streams, but I think it is helpful.

@reta hmm, MP reactive-streams-operators was supposed to redefine (with the same pitfall that it is no more aligned on what people use on the JVM). Seems it hasnt be done but the spec is not yet really part of MP stack I guess, so still a kind of big sandbox ;). 
To be very concrete, today you have 3 kind of (java) users:

1. JVM ones (java >= 11 in general),
2. RxJava ones (they don't care of these abstractions cause they lack too much "helpers",
3. java 8 guys doing what they can (often reactive streams).

Indeed you can bridge between all these impl, even with the standard servlet or jaxrs reactive API (what this PR does) but it just adds noise in apps and is something to maintain in time, this is why I generally try to care to never add a dependency I don't need, and here it is not really needed.

A quick note on the interop which is not always "perfect" (got a few issue with different netty libs if netty was not aligned upfront), can be seen as minor but still.

Then, to be even more concrete, the interesting part of the reactive programming on producer side is the threading and this PR uses common pool which completely breaks the scalability of apps until tuned...on the JVM which prevents the tuning of the app if used anywhere else. So whatever is done, it will need to use a dedicated executor - either in the MP API or through cxf properties/extensions but not the default CXF one which is sized for other kind of requests.

Then in terms of API you just reimpl it completely (cause reactivestreams is not an impl as Rx can be) so importing reactivestreams for 3 interfaces with 2-3 methods is very luxury IMHO.

I'd prefer a module next to the default one enabling to unwrap as a reactive impl the cxf impl rather than the opposite which would enable to embrace all cases and drop reactivestreams when java 8 will be deprecated for example.

Hope it makes sense.

@rmannibucau It certainly makes sense (implementation wise the PR needs some work, the ForkJoin pool was also on my list but I thought to have TCK tests first). Yeah, you seem to have more insights into "real" state of MP specs,  if there is a better alternative to align with directions the MP is going,  I am definitely fine with that (keeping in mind we have to support Java 8). Thanks for the thoughts!
Thanks @andymc12!

Hi @reta @rmannibucau  - sorry for the delay on this.  

* Wrt Java Flow API - I agree that that would be preferable to reactive streams.  I discussed the idea of prereq-ing Java 11 with the MicroProfile community and have been pretty much shot down.  The current MP Reactive Streams Operators uses reactive streams and will continue to do so in MP 4.0.  I'm not giving up hope that we can change their mind though, because the 4.0 release is being delayed due to IP working group issues - so that is more time to plead my case. :-). But for now, I'd like to go ahead with using reactive streams to be consistent with the rest of the MP community.

* Wrt to the reactive streams TCK - I really like that idea.  I'm thinking that it might be preferable to add the RS TCK to the MP Rest Client TCK so that all implementations of MP Rest Client 2.0 must implement a compliant Publisher for InboundSseEvents.  As you both have probably guessed, my initial implementation in this PR is not compliant.  I'm working on both the TCK in the MP project and the CXF implementation in parallel.  

* Wrt the ForkJoinPool - good catch!  I'll plan to use the ExecutionService specified by the RestClientBuilder API, which defaults to the ForkJoinPool if none is specified.  Wdyt?

Thanks for the feedback!
I'll check
@coheigea added tests against Spring Boot and Jetty server

Ok, all the changes are in - and it is passing the Reactive Streams TCK.  I'm thinking I'll still leave the PR in draft mode until the MP Rest Client PR is merged - that way I can publish a milestone build of MP Rest Client that contains the updated TCK.  Once the updated TCK is available from Maven, then I can update the parent pom file and officially verify that this passes both the Reactive Streams TCK and the MP Rest Client TCK.
updated to released 2.3.3 https://github.com/apache/cxf/commit/cd7cbb3aec02654cdd7e891e9e17ef2c0f70888b
@reta - this is now passing the Reactive Streams TCK (which is pulled in as part of the MP Rest Client TCK in 2.0-m1).  Can you take another pass at reviewing the changes?  Thanks!
@reta thanks for the review. I implemented your `MessageContext` idea.  Please let me know if you have any other concerns or suggestions.
@rmannibucau
Seems to work but I haven't check osgi. I think we should target 3.4.0 for merge...
Superseded by #680
